text.p: ** BIRTHDAYS **

Australian pioneer grazier SIR SIDNEY KIDMAN, who ran away from home with 5 shillings and a one-eyed horse and ended up with a chain of properties from Adelaide to the Gulf country, was born in 1857. The combined size of his properties amounted to more than the entire land mass of England.
English writer SIR JAMES BARRIE, whose best known works included "Peter Pan" and "The Admirable Crichton", was born in 1860.
American tennis player PANCHO GONZALEZ, who won the US singles title 8 times, was born in 1928.
British actress GLENDA JACKSON, whose films included the Oscar-winning "Women In Love" and "A Touch Of Class", was born in 1936.

World water-speed record holder KEN WARBY was born in Newcastle in 1939. In October 1978 he became the first person to break the 500 kilometres per hour barrier, when his "Spirit of Australia" flashed across Blowering Dam at 511.11 kph.

American singer BILLY JOEL was born in 1949. The pianist and songwriter formed his first group in 1964 and went solo in 1972. HIs hits included "Just The Way You Are" (1977), "It's Still Rock & Roll To Me" (1980), "Tell Her About It" (1983), "Uptown Girl" (1983) and "We Didn't Start The Fire"(1989).
1927 : The Australian Federal Parliament met for the
first time in Canberra.
1962 : The BEATLES signed a recording contract with EMI's
Parlophone label.
1972 : Israeli troops stormed a hijacked jet in
Jerusalem, freeing 92 passengers held hostage by the Palestinian 'Black September' terrorist organisation.
1978 : The body of kidnapped Italian statesman ALDO MORO
was found in a car in central Rome. He'd been shot 11 times.
1988 : Australia's new Parliament House was inaugurated
in Canberra at a glittering ceremony, attended by Prime Minister BOB HAWKE and Queen ELIZABETH.
1991 : WILLIAM KENNEDY SMITH, the nephew of Senator
EDWARD KENNEDY, was charged with sexual battery.

(Compiled from ABC ARCHIVES, ABC RADIO NATIONAL, "On This Day" published by REED INTERNATIONAL BOOKS LIMITED, "The Chronicle Of The 20th Century" published by PENGUIN BOOKS and "Rock And Pop (Day By Day)" published by BLANDFORD BOOKS.)
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
1915 : Champion New Zealand tennis player ANTHONY WILDING
was killed in action at Lestren in France. The 31-year-old had four Wimbledon singles wins under his belt.
1924 : The Young Women's Christian Association in the
United States said working women should dress strikingly to succeed.
1926 : American explorer RICHARD BYRD became the first
person to fly over the North Pole.
